div.p: JOB, a sub-element available within OCCUPATION and also under MEMBER, within FAMILY, is meant to capture the types of non-literary employment done by women writers and their families. It encloses just a word or phrase describing the job. We are interested in comparing the kinds of jobs women did in different historical periods and the kinds of jobs family members did. We want to facilitate research, for example, on the influence of living in a parsonage on women writers and would therefore like to track women who had fathers and mothers who were ministers. The tag has one optional attribute, REG, which allows you to standardize the name of a job if you have been unable to do so in your prose. By regularizing, the attribute REG serves to group jobs: professor, reader (Britspeak), lecturer are all REG=academic.

div.codeblock: She was a <JOB>teacher</JOB>. She worked as a <JOB>nurse</JOB> during WWI.
She<JOB REG="nurse">attended to the sick</JOB> during her years in Vichy.

div.p: Tag JOB within OCCUPATION only if the job belonged to the subject of the entry. Tag JOB within MEMBER if the job belonged to the subject of the MEMBER tag. We will want to generate separate lists of jobs done by British Women Writers and jobs done by, for example, their mothers or husbands. Be careful with those who hold jobs at British universities, especially Cambridge and Oxford. IMG notes that the title of professor used to be rare there and is still not general. It cannot be the standard form for anyone who teaches at British institutions. Use academic as the REG job attribute; the prose may read things like lecturer or reader or (at Cambridge or Oxford) fellow and tutor or fellow and lecturer. You may place the JOB element around a one-word noun or round a verb or phrase. For example, use She was a <JOB>teacher</JOB> but She <JOB REG=”teacher”>taught</JOB>. If available phrasing sounds remote from the actual job title, use the CURRENTALTERNATIVETERM attribute attached to JOB, to enter a correct title for the job. AA worked in <JOB CURRENTALTERNATIVETERM="ceramicist">ceramics</JOB> and <JOB CURRENTALTERNATIVETERM="designer">design</JOB> at the <EMPLOYER><ORGNAME>Chelsea Pottery</ORGNAME></EMPLOYER>. (It would be worth tagging Chelsea as a PLACE, too.) Writing activities are not jobs. See more under OCCUPATION.
Question: What if all I know is where she worked but not what her job was?

Answer: Include whatever information is available, tag the employer if known and try to phrase the sentence in general terms to capture something of the job. PMS began a <JOB>career in fashion</JOB> and worked at <EMPLOYER><ORGNAME>Christian Dior</ORGNAME></EMPLOYER>.
